data.title: Cincinnati Public Library’s $43.4M project to downtown branch complete
meta_keywords: cincinnati and hamilton county public library
grand opening of cincinnati public library
grand opening of cincinnati and hamilton county public library
Cincinnati Public Library’s $43.4M downtown main branch project complete
Cincinnati Public Library’s $43.4M project to downtown branch complete
data.meta_description: The library is hosting a weekend-full of events to celebrate the reopening.
data.text:
CINCINNATI (WXIX) - It is the beginning of a new era for the Downtown branch of the Cincinnati and Hamilton County Public Library and the end of a $43.4 million renovation project.

The Downtown library, currently located in the two blocks of Vine, Prior, Walnut and East 8th Streets, has been a source of knowledge for thousands of Cincinnati residents since the early 1800s. The current location has been around since 1874 and has managed to survive for more than a century.

Friday, July 12, will be the first official opening day for the library, and staff members are gearing up for a weekend full of celebrating the end of a 4-year plan.

Out with the old, in with the new

Attendees will find redesigned spaces, such as the kids and teens zones, the new Catherine C. and Thomas E. Huenefeld Story Center, a new sculpture called Phronesis, and a refresh to the outdoor plazas. The redesign cost the library a whopping $30.7 million.

Additionally, the library spent millions of dollars on refurbishing the building:

The new roof in the North building cost $1.2 million

Replacing the skylight and elevators in the South building cost $5.9 million

Replacing the original boilers from the 1950s, upgrading the cooling system, adding 14 new air handlers and improving the electrical system in the South building, which cost $5.6 million.

In 2018, Cincinnati residents voted in favor of a 1 mil tax levy that would provide $19 million per year to improve the Cincinnati library. The tax levy began in 2019 and will end in 2028, raising a total of $190 million for the library’s fund.

The public library’s master plan, known as Building the Next Generation Library, was completed in December 2019 with the help of city council members, staff and the public. But the plan is not just for the downtown building, it is also intended for all 41 branches.

Currently, three branch libraries are still being worked on: Forest Park, Mt. Healthy and Symmes Township.

Forest Park Branch

A completely new building, which is located at 660 Northland Blvd.

Over 90 parking spots included at this location

Status: Under construction

Expected to be done in Summer 2024

Estimated investment: $19.2 million

Mt. Healthy Branch

Completely new building, one block away from the original branch. The new location is 7700 Hamilton Ave.

Expected to be done in late 2024

Estimated investment: $5.3 million

Residents of Mt. Healthy asked for the following improvements to be made: More space inside, improved accessibility, more parking, a drive-thru, meeting spots and larger family-friendly restrooms.

Symmes Township Branch

Estimated investment: $16 million

Expected to be done in late 2025, early 2026

Currently in the designing and planning stage

Future branch projects

Avondale: TBD

Blue Ash: TBD

Bond Hill: TBD

Cheviot: Estimated investment of $5.5 million

Clifton: TBD

Covedale: TBD

Delhi Township: Estimated investment of $16.5 million

Harrison: TBD

Loveland: TBD

Mariemont: TBD

Miami Township: $7 million

Monfort Heights: TBD

Mt. Washington: TBD

Northside: TBD

St. Bernard: TBD

Completed branch projects

Anderson

$525,000 investment

New interior, small meeting spaces added and updates to the children’s and teen’s area.

College Hill

$50,000 investment

New carpet and paint, major upgrades to the HVAC and electrical system and new furniture.

Corryville

$2.8 million investment

Waterproofing the perimeter, repairing walls, new paint and carpets, two new study rooms, a new play area for kids and changes to the layout of the branch.

Deer Park

$4.1 million investment

Expanded into the former T.J. Maxx, making it about five times the size of the original location.

Distribution Center

$700,000 investment

Elmwood Place

$15,000

Updated carpet and paint, and new furniture

Green Township

$650,000 investment

New seating, refreshed paint and flooring, accessible restroom, new teen area, relocated quiet study area with space for genealogy research, a creative play space, and updating meeting rooms.

Groesbeck

$100,000 investment

Updates were made to the carpet, newly painted walls, new furniture and three new study rooms.

Hyde Park

$5.8 million

Phase 1: Improvements made to the sewage and drainage system.

Phase 2: Accessibility improvements, new flooring and comfortable furniture, an updated kids area, a new elevator, larger restrooms and improved meeting areas.

Madeira

$75,000 investment

Interior updates, such as painting the walls and updating the carpet. Switching the children’s and adult sections to improve customer service.

Madisonville

$3.3 million investment

Completely new location.

Four new study pods, two meeting rooms, fully accessible restrooms, MakerSpace equipment, more desktops and laptops, eight designated parking spots and new furniture.

North Central

$770,000 investment

Making extensive repairs to the HVAC system

Pleasant Ridge

$1.2 million investment

Maintenance to the exterior of the building, new paint, additional furniture, changes to the interior floor plan and repairing plaster damage.

Price Hill

$73 million investment in the branch’s improvements; $477,000 investment for the parklet (the front lawn of the library)

Expanding the indoor space, designated quiet areas, improvements to accessibility, more parking spots, four meeting rooms and “re-envisioned spaces” for everyone.

Sharonville

$450,000 investment

New furniture, shelving, paint, seating and computers, an expanded children’s section and a reading area with a fireplace.

Walnut Hills

$12.3 million investment

Expanding the library’s overall size, more accessibility, restoration to the lower level floor, two laptop kiosks, maintaining the original Carnegie Library building, wireless and plug-in charging stations, 40 new parking spots, a tablet kiosk, and new study/meeting rooms.

West End

$3 million investment

A vibrant area for kids and teens, a new laptop kiosk, an outdoor patio, two new study spaces available for reservations, accessibility and restroom improvements and a new welcome center.

For more information on the Cincinnati and Hamilton County Public Library’s timeline of projects, visit their website.
